articles.headline: Lesson for P.O.W.’s Father: Men Sometimes Do Come Back
articles.snippet: Robert Bergdahl fought in Washington for his son’s release from the Taliban for five years. On Saturday, President Obama said Bowe Bergdahl was coming home.
articles.abstract: Robert Bergdahl fought in Washington for his son’s release from the Taliban for five years. On Saturday, President Obama said Bowe Bergdahl was coming home.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For five years Robert Bergdahl waged a father’s war for the return of his soldier son.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller, Michael S. Schmidt and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: N.S.A. Collecting Millions of Faces From Web Images
articles.snippet: The National Security Agency’s reliance on facial recognition technology has grown as it has used new software to exploit images in emails, text messages, social media, videoconferences and other communications.
articles.abstract: The National Security Agency’s reliance on facial recognition technology has grown as it has used new software to exploit images in emails, text messages, social media, videoconferences and other communications.
articles.lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency is harvesting huge numbers of images of people from communications that it intercepts through its global surveillance operations for use in sophisticated facial recognition programs, according to top-secret documents.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Laura Poitras

articles.headline: Intruders for the Plugged-In Home, Coming In Through the Internet
articles.snippet: While the connected home will offer plenty of conveniences in the operation of locks, lights and appliances, there likely will also be problems around privacy and other concerns.
articles.abstract: While the connected home will offer plenty of conveniences in the operation of locks, lights and appliances, there likely will also be problems around privacy and other concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home, connected home. The front door opens with a tap on an iPhone. The lights come up as if by magic. The oven sends a text: Dinner is ready.

articles.headline: At WWDC, Apple Is Set to Make Push Into Monitoring Health and Home
articles.snippet: Apple is expected to introduce mobile apps that will track a user’s health and fitness routine, and smart home devices, at its annual Worldwide Developers’ Conference.
articles.abstract: Apple is expected to introduce mobile apps that will track a user’s health and fitness routine, and smart home devices, at its annual Worldwide Developers’ Conference.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is unlikely to introduce new devices this week, the things that most excite customers and investors these days. But the company is expected to dive deeper into two new areas: connected health and the so-called smart home.

articles.headline: Obama to Take Action to Slash Coal Pollution
articles.snippet: The Environmental Protection Agency will unveil a draft proposal on Monday to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030, according to people briefed on the plan.
articles.abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency will unveil a draft proposal on Monday to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030, according to people briefed on the plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday will announce one of the strongest actions ever taken by the United States government to fight climate change, a proposed Environmental Protection Agency regulation to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030, according to people briefed on the plan who spoke anonymously because they had been asked not to reveal details.

articles.headline: Mentally, G.I. Has Long Path Back to Idaho
articles.snippet: Military officials said that the recovery of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl would be a multistep process, beginning with treatment in Germany before further care in the United States.
articles.abstract: Military officials said that the recovery of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl would be a multistep process, beginning with treatment in Germany before further care in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the road home to Idaho began with a brief helicopter ride from the rugged frontier of eastern Afghanistan to Bagram Air Base, north of Kabul. His return to anything close to a normal life will take much longer.

articles.headline: Hachette Chief Leads Book Publishers in Amazon Fight
articles.snippet: Michael Pietsch, chief executive of the Hachette Book Group, finds himself fighting not just for the future of his company, but for that of every publisher that works with Amazon.
articles.abstract: Michael Pietsch, chief executive of the Hachette Book Group, finds himself fighting not just for the future of his company, but for that of every publisher that works with Amazon.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a young book editor at Little, Brown & Company in 1992, Michael Pietsch paid $80,000 — $45,000 more than the next-highest bidder — for a postmodern novel by a little-known writer named David Foster Wallace.

articles.headline: Amazon Absorbing Price Fight Punches
articles.snippet: By blocking inventory from the Hachette Book Group, Amazon has become the less-than-everything store.
articles.abstract: By blocking inventory from the Hachette Book Group, Amazon has become the less-than-everything store.
articles.lead_paragraph: Books, we are told, are relics that have reached their sell-by date, put out by an industry that is a desiccated shell of its former self.

articles.headline: Insider-Trading Inquiry Could Rattle Icahn’s Efforts to Shape His Legacy
articles.snippet: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has a record as an activist investor that rivals call enviable, but it could be scorched by a spotlight turned harsh.
articles.abstract: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has a record as an activist investor that rivals call enviable, but it could be scorched by a spotlight turned harsh.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Carl C. Icahn has enjoyed the spotlight.

articles.headline: Scots Are Divided Over Independence, and Its Economic Costs
articles.snippet: Voices inside and outside Scotland are warning of the implications of leaving the United Kingdom, even as supporters say Scotland would be better off by itself.
articles.abstract: Voices inside and outside Scotland are warning of the implications of leaving the United Kingdom, even as supporters say Scotland would be better off by itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEITH, Scotland — The case for tearing apart the United Kingdom was made on a recent evening at a community center in this small town near Glasgow. More than 200 people were packed into folding chairs and standing along walls lined with posters promoting an independent Scotland, like the one with the word “Aye” emblazoned on a Scottish flag. A disco ball hung overhead.

articles.headline: Before Brief, Deadly Spree, Trouble Since Age 8
articles.snippet: Before Elliot O. Rodger killed six people and took his own life in Isla Vista, Calif., his mental health and increasingly withdrawn behavior worried his parents and others.
articles.abstract: Before Elliot O. Rodger killed six people and took his own life in Isla Vista, Calif., his mental health and increasingly withdrawn behavior worried his parents and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was the summer of 1999, and the parents of Elliot O. Rodger were battling over the boy’s deep and puzzling psychological problems as they struggled through a divorce.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Michael Cieply, Alan Feuer and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: Prisoner Trade Yields Rare View Into the Taliban
articles.snippet: Representatives of both sides played down the idea that the exchange, long seen as a crucial prelude to any broader talks, might breathe new life into a peace effort.
articles.abstract: Representatives of both sides played down the idea that the exchange, long seen as a crucial prelude to any broader talks, might breathe new life into a peace effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The freeing of five senior Taliban figures in exchange for the American soldier, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, has offered both a rare insight into the insurgent group’s inner workings and a diplomatic first in the long Afghan war: a negotiated agreement between the highest levels of the American government and the pinnacle of the Taliban command.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: Tales of Army Discord Show Tiananmen Square in a New Light
articles.snippet: In 1989, a Chinese general refused to take part in violence against protesters, sending tremors through the Communist Party establishment, documents and interviews show.
articles.abstract: In 1989, a Chinese general refused to take part in violence against protesters, sending tremors through the Communist Party establishment, documents and interviews show.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — On a spring evening in 1989, with the student occupation of Tiananmen Square entering its second month and the Chinese leadership unnerved and divided, top army commanders were summoned to headquarters to pledge their support for the use of military force to quash the protests.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: New System for Treating Cancer Seen as Hopeful
articles.snippet: But promising treatments to fight advanced melanoma with immunotherapy — drugs that use the body’s immune system — also had severe side effects in studies.
articles.abstract: But promising treatments to fight advanced melanoma with immunotherapy — drugs that use the body’s immune system — also had severe side effects in studies.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Drugs that unleash the body’s immune system to combat tumors could allow patients with advanced melanoma to live far longer than ever before, researchers gathered at the nation’s largest cancer conference say.

articles.headline: Secret Global Strike Kills 2 Malicious Web Viruses
articles.snippet: A coordinated effort by government agents in the United States and Europe aimed at two pernicious viruses also led to the identity of the Russian man suspected of masterminding the malware.
articles.abstract: A coordinated effort by government agents in the United States and Europe aimed at two pernicious viruses also led to the identity of the Russian man suspected of masterminding the malware.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal agents over the weekend secretly seized control of two computer networks that hackers used to steal millions of dollars from unsuspecting victims. In doing so, the Justice Department disrupted the circulation of two of the world’s most pernicious viruses and turned a 30-year-old Russian computer hacker into a most-wanted fugitive.
